messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A Topological Characterization of Modulo-ùëù Arguments and Implications for Necklace Splitting

Paper Abstract: Abstract The classes PPA-pùëùp have attracted attention lately, because they are the main candidates for capturing the complexity of Necklace Splitting with pùëùp thieves, for prime pùëùp. However, these classes were not known to have complete problems of a topological nature, which impedes any progress towards settling the complexity of the Necklace Splitting problem. On the contrary, topological problems have been pivotal in obtaining completeness results for PPAD and PPA, such as the PPAD-completeness of finding a Nash equilibrium (Daskalakis et al., 2009; Chen et al., 2009b) and the PPA-completeness of Necklace Splitting with 222 thieves (Filos-Ratsikas and Goldberg, 2019). In this paper, we provide the first topological characterization of the classes PPA-pùëùp. First, we show that the computational problem associated with a simple generalization of Tucker‚Äôs Lemma, termed pùëùp-polygon-Tucker, as well as the associated Borsuk-Ulam-type theorem, pùëùp-polygon-Borsuk-Ulam, are PPA-pùëùp-complete. Then, we show that the computational version of the well-known BSS Theorem (B√°r√°ny, Shlosman, and Sz√ºcs, 1981), as well as the associated BSS-Tucker problem are PPA-pùëùp-complete. Finally, using a different generalization of Tucker‚Äôs Lemma (termed ‚Ñ§psubscript‚Ñ§ùëù\mathbb{Z}_{p}-star-Tucker), which we prove to be PPA-pùëùp-complete, we prove that pùëùp-thief Necklace Splitting is in PPA-pùëùp. This latter result gives a new combinatorial proof for the Necklace Splitting theorem, the only proof of this nature other than that of Meunier (2014). All of our containment results are obtained through a new combinatorial proof for ‚Ñ§psubscript‚Ñ§ùëù\mathbb{Z}_{p}-versions of Tucker‚Äôs lemma that is a natural generalization of the standard combinatorial proof of Tucker‚Äôs lemma by Freund and Todd (1981). We believe that this new proof technique is of independent interest.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "2-D Tucker is PPA complete",
        "Splitting necklaces",
        "Some recent combinatorial applications of Borsuk-type theorems",
        "Non-constructive proofs in combinatorics",
        "Efficient splitting of measures and necklaces",
        "The Borsuk-Ulam Theorem and Bisection of Necklaces",
        "The chromatic number of Kneser hypergraphs",
        "On a topological generalization of a theorem of Tverberg",
        "The Relative Complexity of NP Search Problems",
        "How to assemble tree machines (Extended Abstract)",
        "Drei S√§tze √ºber die n-dimensionale euklidische Sph√§re",
        "Fast multiple-precision evaluation of elementary functions",
        "√úber Abbildung von Mannigfaltigkeiten",
        "On the complexity of 2d discrete fixed point problem",
        "Settling the complexity of Arrow-Debreu equilibria in markets with additively separable utilities",
        "Settling the complexity of computing two-player Nash equilibria",
        "The complexity of non-monotone markets",
        "D√©monstration d‚Äôune hypoth√®se de M. Artin",
        "Continuous local search",
        "The complexity of computing a Nash equilibrium",
        "The Borsuk-Ulam-property, Tucker-property and constructive proofs in combinatorics",
        "Algorithmic solutions for envy-free cake cutting",
        "Simple proofs of some Borsuk-Ulam results",
        "A generalization of the ham sandwich theorem",
        "On the complexity of Nash equilibria and other fixed points",
        "The complexity of gradient descent: CLS = PPAD ‚à©\\cap PLS",
        "Consensus Halving is PPA-complete",
        "The Complexity of Splitting Necklaces and Bisecting Ham Sandwiches",
        "Hardness Results for Consensus-Halving",
        "Consensus-Halving: Does it Ever Get Easier?",
        "Variable dimension complexes part I: Basic theory",
        "A constructive proof of Tucker‚Äôs combinatorial lemma",
        "Bisection of Circle Colorings",
        "The Hairy Ball Problem is PPAD-Complete",
        "On the Complexity of Modulo-q Arguments and the Chevalley-Warning Theorem",
        "A Sperner lemma complete for PPA",
        "Algebraic topology",
        "A moment problem in L1 approximation",
        "The Classes PPA-k: Existence from Arguments Modulo k",
        "Reductions and Propositional Proofs for Total NP Search Problems",
        "Aufgabe 360",
        "Some combinatorial lemmas in topology",
        "Kneser‚Äôs conjecture, chromatic number, and homotopy",
        "Using the Borsuk-Ulam theorem: lectures on topological methods in combinatorics and geometry",
        "On total functions, existence theorems and computational complexity",
        "Constant rank bimatrix games are PPAD-hard",
        "Discrete Splittings of the Necklace",
        "Simplotopal maps and necklace splitting",
        "Computing solutions of the paintshop-necklace problem",
        "Paintshop, odd cycles and necklace splitting",
        "Elements of algebraic topology",
        "Un th√©or√®me d‚Äôexistence",
        "On the complexity of the parity argument and other inefficient proofs of existence",
        "Inapproximability of Nash equilibrium",
        "A generalized van Kampen-Flores theorem",
        "Consensus-halving via theorems of Borsuk-Ulam and Tucker",
        "PPP-completeness with connections to cryptography",
        "Neuer Beweis f√ºr die Invarianz der Dimensionszahl und des Gebietes",
        "Some topological properties of disk and sphere",
        "Bemerkung zur vorstehenden Arbeit",
        "Generalized Kneser coloring theorems with combinatorial proofs",
        "An extension of the ham sandwich theorem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A Topological Characterization of Modulo-ùëù Arguments and Implications for Necklace Splitting, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
